body: What is a `.desktop` file and where/why should we ship one?

> X-Gnome-Autostart=true

Won't this make Syncthing auto-started by default?

> Terminal=false

... and in background on top of that?

Generally, stuff that doesn't have any sort of GUI doesn't have desktop files. From user perspective, clicking on such icon does nothing. If starting Syncthing daemon from applications menu is desired, at least set Terminal to true, so clicking will open _something_.

> What is a .desktop file and where/why should we ship one?

They are files that define how applications should appear/behave in menus, etc.

In Debian, they are installed in `/usr/share/applications`.

Documentation/Specification of the .desktop files can be found here: https://specifications.freedesktop.org/desktop-entry-spec/latest/index.html#introduction

> Generally, stuff that doesn't have any sort of GUI doesn't have desktop files

Exactly, this is why I said that I would prefer merging the two files. The above files were just a suggestion by a user of the package.

I think clicking on the Syncthing icon should launch the daemon (if its not running) and open the UI in a browser. Do we agree with that?

Suggestion:

The desktop entry of Syncthing can use a mechanism to prevent launching multiple daemons for a user. I am sure a script can check if there is already a `syncthing@user` service running, and then launch the daemon if not. Then we can avoid launching two non-systemd-managed daemons with pid files in `/var/run/syncthing/syncthing-user.pid`.

It looks like launching Syncthing two times isn't problematic anyways (we should still try not to do it):

```
[DPBP6] 11:55:23 INFO: syncthing v0.13.10-dfsg1 "Copper Cockroach" (go1.6.2 linux-amd64) debian@debian 2016-07-04 10:12:49 UTC
[DPBP6] 11:55:23 INFO: My ID: DPBP67K-4NGZEVR-VT7KMCC-CPPJWMM-MB3BGCX-6TSBD26-MGUFIAE-MWY6VAW
[DPBP6] 11:55:23 INFO: Single thread hash performance is ~184 MB/s
[DPBP6] 11:55:23 FATAL: Cannot open database: resource temporarily unavailable - Is another copy of Syncthing already running?
[monitor] 11:55:23 INFO: Syncthing exited: exit status 1
[monitor] 11:55:24 WARNING: 4 restarts in 5.367237722s; not retrying further
```

`syncthing -browser-only` starts the GUI.

This looks Gnome specific. We might want to put that in the Debian package anyway if that's what's Debian is standardized on. I'll let you all hash out the details.

> syncthing@user service running, and then launch the daemon if not.
> Then we can avoid launching two non-systemd-managed daemons with pid files in /var/run/syncthing/syncthing-user.pid.

I shall note that now you are assuming not only graphical session with Gnome, but even Linux with systemd :)

Desktop file can use [OnlyShowIn](https://specifications.freedesktop.org/desktop-entry-spec/latest/ar01s05.html#key-onlyshowin) if you are targeting only Gnome, but depending on specific service manager and existence of `/var/run` may end with script that fails to do anything.

> I shall note that now you are assuming not only graphical session with Gnome

Why? Is there anything that I said that is gnome-specific?

> but even Linux with systemd :)

Absolutely not. The script can check for systemd's presence on the system.

> but depending on specific service manager and existence of /var/run may

Packages usually ensure the existence of /var/run, so there is no issue there.

> Why? Is there anything that I said that is gnome-specific?

`X-Gnome-Autostart=true`. Less gnome-specific way would be to install desktop file to `/etc/xdg/autostart`.
Once again, I repeat that this desktop entry file is just a suggestion that I quoted from the submitter of the bug. Its here as an example, not for review.

Given that the officially recommended usage is per-user started when the user logs in, I'd say that this is a good thing to add.

There are of course other cases on Linux (servers, or single user systems where there's not always a GUI running), but most of the people who need such a configuration are probably smart enough to figure out how to set that up themselves (or are using Gentoo, which ships the stuff required to run Syncthing as a regular daemon).

Also, there's a decent number of things that don't have  GUI that have desktop files, most people never think about them though (stuff like PulseAudio, the GNOME keyring daemon, ssh-agents, and similar things that are per-session and started at login).  In fact, if this is being auto-started, I'd very much say we should have two files, one only in the auto-start directory which does not start a browser pointed at the UI, and one which just pups-up the UI.  Auto-starting something with a GUI that isn't part of the desktop environment and wasn't specifically requested by the user is not a good thing from a usability perspective.

The places where we would ship this is
- In the expected place in our Debian packages, to fit with what Debian expects specifically.
- In the `etc/` directory that we anyway fill with start scripts and crap.

As such it's fine if it is somewhat Debian specific and makes Debian specific assumptions.

But perhaps doing any of this cleanly requires a `-deamonize-if-not-running-and-then-open-browser` command line switch which currently doesn't exist. Of course something similar could be hacked together as a shell script as well.

Anyway. Unplanned, contributions welcome. :)

issue.title: chore: gnome-shell autostart

labels.name: frozen-due-to-age
labels.description: Issues closed and untouched for a long time, together with being locked for discussion

issue.body:
### Purpose

Provides sample for gnome-shell startup integration

### Testing

Has been tested on RHEL 7.4 with Gnome shell.
